content.content:
# Claude Code Documentation Navigation

I'm Claude Code, Anthropic's CLI tool for AI-assisted development. I can help you find documentation across our comprehensive map.

## Key Documentation Areas

**Getting Started**: The [overview](https://code.claude.com/docs/en/overview.md) and [quickstart](https://code.claude.com/docs/en/quickstart.md) guides cover installation and first steps.

**Common Workflows**: Documentation includes [code understanding](https://code.claude.com/docs/en/common-workflows.md), bug fixing, refactoring, testing, and creating pull requests.

**Building Features**: Learn about [subagents](https://code.claude.com/docs/en/sub-agents.md), [plugins](https://code.claude.com/docs/en/plugins.md), [skills](https://code.claude.com/docs/en/skills.md), and [custom slash commands](https://code.claude.com/docs/en/slash-commands.md).

**Deployment**: Configuration guides for [AWS Bedrock](https://code.claude.com/docs/en/amazon-bedrock.md), [Google Vertex AI](https://code.claude.com/docs/en/google-vertex-ai.md), and [GitHub Actions](https://code.claude.com/docs/en/github-actions.md) integration.

**Administration**: Team setup includes [IAM](https://code.claude.com/docs/en/iam.md), [security](https://code.claude.com/docs/en/security.md), [monitoring](https://code.claude.com/docs/en/monitoring-usage.md), and [costs](https://code.claude.com/docs/en/costs.md).

## How Can I Help?

Ask about specific features, setup instructions, or documentation topics. I can guide you to the right resources.

content.content:
# Claude Code Setup Overview

Based on the documentation provided, here's what you need to know about setting up Claude Code:

## Key Requirements
Claude Code requires macOS 10.15+, Ubuntu 20.04+, Debian 10+, or Windows 10+ with WSL/Git Bash. You'll need at least 4GB RAM, Node.js 18+ (for NPM installation only), and internet connectivity for authentication.

## Installation Methods
The recommended approach is native installation through Homebrew, curl scripts, or PowerShell. Alternatively, you can install via NPM: `npm install -g @anthropic-ai/claude-code`. After installation, navigate to your project and run `claude` to launch.

## Authentication Options
Three authentication paths are available:

1. **Claude Console**: Default option requiring active billing at console.anthropic.com
2. **Claude App**: Available with Pro or Max subscription plans
3. **Enterprise platforms**: Amazon Bedrock, Google Vertex AI, or Microsoft Foundry integration

As the documentation notes, "Claude Code securely stores your credentials."

## Windows-Specific Setup
Windows users can either run Claude Code within WSL (1 or 2 supported) or use Git Bash on native Windows.

## Automatic Updates
The tool automatically updates itself by default. To disable this feature, set `DISABLE_AUTOUPDATER=1` in your environment or settings.json file.

For troubleshooting, run `claude doctor` to verify your installation status and version.

# Claude Code Setup Overview

Based on the documentation provided, here's what you need to know about setting up Claude Code:

## Key Requirements
Claude Code requires macOS 10.15+, Ubuntu 20.04+, Debian 10+, or Windows 10+ with WSL/Git Bash. You'll need at least 4GB RAM, Node.js 18+ (for NPM installation only), and internet connectivity for authentication.

## Installation Methods
The recommended approach is native installation through Homebrew, curl scripts, or PowerShell. Alternatively, you can install via NPM: `npm install -g @anthropic-ai/claude-code`. After installation, navigate to your project and run `claude` to launch.

## Authentication Options
Three authentication paths are available:

1. **Claude Console**: Default option requiring active billing at console.anthropic.com
2. **Claude App**: Available with Pro or Max subscription plans
3. **Enterprise platforms**: Amazon Bedrock, Google Vertex AI, or Microsoft Foundry integration

As the documentation notes, "Claude Code securely stores your credentials."

## Windows-Specific Setup
Windows users can either run Claude Code within WSL (1 or 2 supported) or use Git Bash on native Windows.

## Automatic Updates
The tool automatically updates itself by default. To disable this feature, set `DISABLE_AUTOUPDATER=1` in your environment or settings.json file.

For troubleshooting, run `claude doctor` to verify your installation status and version.

content.content:
# Claude Code Plugins Overview

Based on the documentation provided, here's what you need to know about Claude Code plugins:

## What Plugins Do

Plugins extend Claude Code functionality through "custom commands, agents, hooks, Skills, and MCP servers." They enable workflow automation and can be shared across teams and projects.

## Key Components

A plugin typically includes:

- **Plugin manifest** (`.claude-plugin/plugin.json`) - Contains metadata
- **Commands directory** - Custom slash commands in markdown format
- **Agents directory** - Custom agent definitions
- **Skills directory** - Agent capabilities with `SKILL.md` files
- **Hooks** - Event handlers via `hooks.json`
- **MCP servers** - External tool integration via `.mcp.json`

## Installation Methods

You can install plugins either through the interactive `/plugin` menu for discovery or via direct commands like `/plugin install formatter@your-org` for quick setup.

## Team Workflows

Teams can configure plugins automatically by adding marketplace and plugin specifications to `.claude/settings.json` in their repository. This ensures consistent tooling across team members.

## Development Path

Developers can create local test marketplaces to develop and iterate on plugins before sharing them widely. The documentation emphasizes testing components individually and validating directory structures at the plugin root level.

Based on the documentation provided, here's what you need to know about Claude Code plugins:

## What Plugins Do

Plugins extend Claude Code functionality through "custom commands, agents, hooks, Skills, and MCP servers." They enable workflow automation and can be shared across teams and projects.

## Key Components

A plugin typically includes:

- **Plugin manifest** (`.claude-plugin/plugin.json`) - Contains metadata
- **Commands directory** - Custom slash commands in markdown format
- **Agents directory** - Custom agent definitions
- **Skills directory** - Agent capabilities with `SKILL.md` files
- **Hooks** - Event handlers via `hooks.json`
- **MCP servers** - External tool integration via `.mcp.json`

## Installation Methods

You can install plugins either through the interactive `/plugin` menu for discovery or via direct commands like `/plugin install formatter@your-org` for quick setup.

## Team Workflows

Teams can configure plugins automatically by adding marketplace and plugin specifications to `.claude/settings.json` in their repository. This ensures consistent tooling across team members.

## Development Path

Developers can create local test marketplaces to develop and iterate on plugins before sharing them widely. The documentation emphasizes testing components individually and validating directory structures at the plugin root level.

content.text: Now let me get more specific information about MCP server configuration:

input.prompt: How to configure MCP servers globally
MCP server configuration and global setup

content.content:
# Configuring MCP Servers Globally

To configure MCP servers globally (available across all projects), use the **user scope**:

```bash
claude mcp add --transport http hubspot --scope user https://mcp.hubspot.com/anthropic
```

This stores the configuration at the user level, making servers "available across all projects on your machine while remaining private to your user account."

## Key Points:

- **User-scoped servers** work well for "personal utilities needed across multiple projects, development tools, or frequently-used services"
- They're stored in your user configuration (not per-project)
- Use `--scope user` flag to explicitly set this scope
- Manage them with standard commands: `claude mcp list`, `claude mcp get`, `claude mcp remove`

For enterprise environments, administrators can also deploy centralized MCP configurations via `managed-mcp.json` files in system directories, giving them "control over MCP servers employees can access" and the ability to "prevent unauthorized MCP servers."

toolUseResult.result:
# Configuring MCP Servers Globally

To configure MCP servers globally (available across all projects), use the **user scope**:

```bash
claude mcp add --transport http hubspot --scope user https://mcp.hubspot.com/anthropic
```

This stores the configuration at the user level, making servers "available across all projects on your machine while remaining private to your user account."

## Key Points:

- **User-scoped servers** work well for "personal utilities needed across multiple projects, development tools, or frequently-used services"
- They're stored in your user configuration (not per-project)
- Use `--scope user` flag to explicitly set this scope
- Manage them with standard commands: `claude mcp list`, `claude mcp get`, `claude mcp remove`

For enterprise environments, administrators can also deploy centralized MCP configurations via `managed-mcp.json` files in system directories, giving them "control over MCP servers employees can access" and the ability to "prevent unauthorized MCP servers."

content.content:
# Agent Skills in Claude Code

Agent Skills extend Claude's capabilities through modular, organized folders containing instructions and resources. Here's what you need to know:

## Key Concepts

**Model-Invoked Activation**: Unlike slash commands that you explicitly trigger, skills activate automatically when Claude determines they're relevant to your request.

**Two Storage Locations**:
- **Personal Skills** (`~/.claude/skills/`): Available across all projects
- **Project Skills** (`.claude/skills/`): Shared with your team via git

## Creating a Skill

Each skill requires a `SKILL.md` file with YAML frontmatter:

```yaml
---
name: skill-name
description: What it does and when to use it
---
```

The description is critical—it should specify both functionality and trigger conditions so Claude can discover when to apply the skill.

## Best Practices

- **Stay focused**: One skill should address one capability, not broad domains
- **Write specific descriptions**: Include concrete triggers (e.g., "Excel files," "PDF forms") rather than vague terms
- **Include examples**: Show how Claude should use the skill
- **Test with teammates**: Verify the skill activates as expected

## Troubleshooting

If Claude isn't using your skill, check:
1. Description specificity and relevance
2. Valid YAML syntax
3. Correct file path and directory structure
4. Dependencies are installed

Skills can include supporting files (scripts, templates, documentation) referenced from the main `SKILL.md` file.

# Agent Skills in Claude Code

Agent Skills extend Claude's capabilities through modular, organized folders containing instructions and resources. Here's what you need to know:

## Key Concepts

**Model-Invoked Activation**: Unlike slash commands that you explicitly trigger, skills activate automatically when Claude determines they're relevant to your request.

**Two Storage Locations**:
- **Personal Skills** (`~/.claude/skills/`): Available across all projects
- **Project Skills** (`.claude/skills/`): Shared with your team via git

## Creating a Skill

Each skill requires a `SKILL.md` file with YAML frontmatter:

```yaml
---
name: skill-name
description: What it does and when to use it
---
```

The description is critical—it should specify both functionality and trigger conditions so Claude can discover when to apply the skill.

## Best Practices

- **Stay focused**: One skill should address one capability, not broad domains
- **Write specific descriptions**: Include concrete triggers (e.g., "Excel files," "PDF forms") rather than vague terms
- **Include examples**: Show how Claude should use the skill
- **Test with teammates**: Verify the skill activates as expected

## Troubleshooting

If Claude isn't using your skill, check:
1. Description specificity and relevance
2. Valid YAML syntax
3. Correct file path and directory structure
4. Dependencies are installed

Skills can include supporting files (scripts, templates, documentation) referenced from the main `SKILL.md` file.

content.text:
Perfect! I found the information you need. Here's how to configure MCP servers globally in Claude Code:

## Configuring MCP Servers Globally

To add an MCP server globally so it's accessible from any directory, use the **user scope** flag with the `claude mcp add` command:

```bash
claude mcp add --scope user <server-name> <configuration>
```

### For the Todoist MCP Server

To add Todoist globally, the command would be:

```bash
claude mcp add --scope user todoist <todoist-mcp-url>
```

Replace `<todoist-mcp-url>` with the appropriate Todoist MCP server endpoint if needed.

## Key Points About User-Scoped Servers

- **Availability**: User-scoped servers are available across all projects on your machine
- **Privacy**: They remain private to your user account
- **Storage**: Configuration is stored in your user configuration directory (not per-project)
- **Use cases**: Personal utilities, development tools, or frequently-used services are ideal candidates for user scope

## Managing Global MCP Servers

Once configured, you can manage your global MCP servers with:

```bash
claude mcp list           # View all configured MCP servers
claude mcp get todoist    # Get details about a specific server
claude mcp remove todoist # Remove a server
```

## Note on Current Configuration

You already have the Todoist MCP server configured in your project (as shown in your `settings.json`), but it appears to be project-scoped. If you want it globally accessible, you'll need to run the `claude mcp add --scope user` command to configure it at the user level.

For additional details and other configuration scopes, you can run `/help mcp` in Claude Code or check the MCP documentation at https://code.claude.com/docs/en/mcp.md.
